Start by identifying smaller gatherings or events where you feel more comfortable, and gradually work your way up to larger ones. This gradual exposure can help desensitize you to the anxiety triggers over time.

Another strategy that may be helpful is practicing relaxation techniques. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body when you start feeling anxious. You can find guided exercises online or through smartphone apps that can assist you in learning these techniques.

Additionally, it could be beneficial to challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs you have about yourself in social situations. Often, people with anxiety tend to underestimate their abilities and overestimate potential negative outcomes. Try to identify any irrational thoughts and replace them with more realistic and positive ones.

Building a support network of understanding friends or family members who can provide encouragement and reassurance can also be valuable. Sometimes having someone by your side during social events can help alleviate anxiety.

Lastly, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide you with personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and progress may come in small steps. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You're not alone, and there are resources available to help you along the way.

It sounds like you're going through a really difficult time right now with these severe anxiety attacks. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms. Here are some suggestions:

1. Deep breathing exercises: When you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try focusing on your breath. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help regulate your heart rate and bring a sense of calm.

2. Grounding techniques: During an anxiety attack, it can be helpful to ground yourself in the present moment. Try focusing on your senses by noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This can help redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts.

3. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tension often builds up during anxiety attacks, so progressive muscle relaxation can be beneficial. Start by tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This can help release tension and promote relaxation.

4. Self-care: Taking care of yourself is crucial when dealing with anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Consider incorporating exercise into your routine as it can help reduce anxiety symptoms.

5. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a helpful way to process and manage anxiety. Try keeping a journal where you can freely express yourself without judgment. It can also be useful to identify any triggers or patterns that may contribute to your anxiety attacks.

6. Support system: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide support and understanding. Sometimes just talking about what you're going through can help alleviate some of the anxiety. If you don't have someone close to confide in, consider seeking support from online communities or helplines.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but can be helpful in managing anxiety symptoms. It's important to prioritize your mental health and seek support from a healthcare professional if your symptoms persist or worsen.

One technique that many individuals find beneficial during anxiety attacks is deep breathing exercises. When you feel an attack coming on, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help calm your mind and body.

Another technique you might find useful is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This exercise can help relax your muscles and reduce overall tension.

Engaging in regular physical activity can have a positive impact on both your mental and physical well-being. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood-boosting chemicals in the brain. Additionally, consider reaching out to friends, family, or support groups who may be able to provide emotional support and guidance. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about us can give us new perspectives and insights.

Another idea is to seek out self-help resources such as books, podcasts, or online courses that align with your goals or areas of interest. These resources can provide valuable information and tools to help you move forward.

Lastly, taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Make sure you're getting regular exercise, eating nutritious meals, and getting enough sleep. Small changes in these areas can make a big difference in how you feel overall.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There are people who care and want to support you. Keep reaching out and exploring different avenues until you find what works best for you. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges.

It sounds like you've had some difficult experiences with feeling excluded and not understanding why certain people seem to dislike you. This can be a challenging situation to navigate, but it's important to remember that everyone has their own unique experiences and perspectives. It's possible that the people you mentioned may have had their own reasons for behaving the way they did, which may or may not have had anything to do with you.

In situations where you feel like others might be treating you differently, it can be helpful to focus on your own self-worth and value as an individual. Remember that your worth is not determined by the opinions of others. Instead, try to surround yourself with positive influences and supportive relationships that uplift and validate you.

Building strong connections with others can also help create a sense of belonging and reduce feelings of isolation. Consider reaching out to people who share similar interests or values, and joining groups or activities where you can meet like-minded individuals. By engaging in activities you enjoy and finding common ground with others, you may find it easier to form meaningful connections.

Additionally, practicing good communication skills can be beneficial in fostering positive interactions. Active listening, empathy, and expressing yourself assertively can help improve the quality of your relationships. Remember that effective communication involves both speaking and listening, so make an effort to genuinely listen to others and understand their perspectives as well.

If you continue to struggle with these feelings, it might be helpful to explore this topic further with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can help you develop strategies to cope with any underlying emotions or beliefs that may be contributing to your concerns.

Remember, you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. Focus on building a strong sense of self-worth, surround yourself with positive influences, and practice effective communication skills. With time and effort, you can cultivate fulfilling relationships and build a support system that will uplift you.

It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. Losing interest in things you used to enjoy can be incredibly disheartening, and it's understandable that it feels difficult to find the motivation to do the things you're supposed to do.

Firstly, please remember that you deserve help and support, regardless of how hopeless you may feel. It takes a lot of strength to reach out for help, and I encourage you to take small steps towards seeking support. One suggestion is to consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer a listening ear or even accompany you on your journey to finding professional help.

When it comes to finding motivation, it might be helpful to start by focusing on self-compassion. Be kind to yourself and acknowledge that it's okay to have ups and downs. Celebrate small victories, even if they seem insignificant. For example, instead of pressuring yourself to complete an entire study session, try setting small goals like studying for just 10 minutes. Gradually increase the time as you start feeling more comfortable.

Additionally, try to incorporate activities that bring you joy, even if they don't seem as enjoyable as before. Engaging in activities that used to make you happy can help lift your mood over time. It might also be helpful to explore new hobbies or interests that you haven't tried before. Sometimes, trying something new can reignite your passion and provide a fresh perspective.

Remember, it's important to take care of your physical health as well. While it may feel challenging, incorporating regular exercise into your routine can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Start with small, manageable steps, such as taking short walks or finding simple exercises you enjoy.

Lastly, please remember that seeking professional help is crucial. A mental health professional can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you navigate through this difficult period. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, exploring underlying causes of your feelings, and provide support throughout your journey.

You are not alone in this, and there is hope for a brighter future. It takes time and effort, but with the right support and self-compassion, you can find motivation and regain your sense of purpose.

It's not uncommon for individuals with anxiety and panic disorder to experience a cycle of hyper-fixation on different worries or fears. This can be a challenging experience, but there are strategies that may help you break this pattern. 

One approach you might find helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. By working with a therapist trained in CBT, you can learn techniques to reframe your thoughts and develop more balanced perspectives. This can help reduce the intensity of your anxiety and make it easier to let go of one worry before latching onto another.

Another technique you could explore is mindfulness meditation. Mindfulness involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment. It can help you become more aware of your anxious thoughts and emotions as they arise, allowing you to observe them without getting caught up in them. Over time, regular practice of mindfulness can help you develop a greater sense of control over your anxiety and reduce its impact on your daily life.

In addition to therapy and mindfulness, self-care practices can play an important role in managing anxiety. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help counteract the stress and tension associated with anxiety. Consider incorporating things like exercise, hobbies, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones into your routine. Taking care of your physical health through proper sleep, nutrition, and avoiding excessive caffeine or alcohol can also have a positive impact on your overall well-being.

Lastly, remember that progress takes time and patience. It's normal to have setbacks along the way, but don't let that discourage you. Celebrate each small victory and keep reminding yourself that you're making progress. With consistent effort and support, it's possible to break free from the cycle of hyper-fixation and find greater peace and control in your life.

It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed with your struggle to brush your hair. Taking care of thick, curly hair can be challenging, especially if you're not sure how to properly do it. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Start by detangling: Before attempting to brush your hair, it can be helpful to first detangle any knots or tangles. You can use a wide-tooth comb or your fingers to gently work through the knots, starting from the ends of your hair and gradually working your way up.

2. Use the right products: Using the right products can make a big difference in managing thick, curly hair. Look for shampoos and conditioners specifically formulated for curly hair. These products often contain ingredients that help moisturize and define curls, making them easier to manage.

3. Deep condition regularly: Deep conditioning treatments can be beneficial for curly hair. They help restore moisture and strengthen the hair shaft. Consider using a deep conditioner once a week or every other week, depending on your hair's needs.

4. Try different brushes: Not all brushes are created equal, and finding the right one for your hair type can make a significant difference. Experiment with different types of brushes, such as boar bristle brushes or paddle brushes, to see which one works best for you.

5. Section your hair: When brushing, it can be helpful to divide your hair into smaller sections. This allows you to focus on one area at a time and prevents tangles from forming. Start by taking a small section of hair and brush it thoroughly before moving on to the next section.

6. Be gentle: Curly hair is more prone to breakage, so it's important to be gentle when brushing. Avoid pulling or tugging at knots, as this can cause damage. Instead, take your time and gently detangle your hair using the techniques mentioned above.

7. Consider protective styles: Protective styles, such as braids or buns, can help protect your hair from damage caused by everyday activities like brushing. If you find that brushing your hair is consistently causing breakage, consider trying out different protective styles to give your hair a break.

Remember, everyone's hair is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for
